content: I regret you are having all of these problems. I agree the new format looks different and I fully concur that the need for CSS to restore the prior view is a strong signal that this could have been done better. I discourage reverting to prior versions because they are at end-of-life. The new release does have its challenges, but most who stay the course eventually get it set as desired. I was one of those who struggled as well. However, what you requested was the prior version. That would be 102.15.1 and here is the link for the 64-bit version. https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/102.15.1/win64/ And please remember that we on this forum are volunteers: we did not design the update, were not allowed to vote on the update, and certainly did not write any of the code. We just try to help people use it. Thanks for sharing your thoughts.
creator: davidsk

content:
It works here in TB 115/W11, although the process is Send to, Mail Recipient, not Thunderbird. It might be the Outlook installation that corrupted the operation for other mail clients. When these types of MAPI issues occur, it can sometimes be fixed by doing this: download and run the installer for the same version already installed:

https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/115.4.1/win64/

Choose Advanced setup, set TB as the default, don't run TB at the end of setup, restart the computer. See if Send to works with multiple files.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1323685

Make sure that Outlook is not set as the default - there could be several places in Windows or Outlook settings.
creator: sfhowes

content:
ccrsedona said
I can't change that is seems, it's automated from outlook, is there a manual way?

IMAP or POP can be selected on the first screen when adding an account to TB. But if an existing account is POP or IMAP, and you wish to switch to the other type, it's not sufficient to just change the settings:

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Convert_a_POP_account_to_a_IMAP_account

To delete, copy or move multiple messages, select the first message, then hold Shift and select the last messages, then press Delete (or copy or move). Press Ctrl while selecting messages that aren't in a single block.

https://www.lifewire.com/select-multiple-files-in-windows-5217221
creator: sfhowes

creator: ccrsedona

content: Is the first one a POP account while the second is IMAP? With IMAP, mail is stored on the server and shown in TB when the account is synced. Syncing also means actions in TB are performed on the server, and vice versa.
creator: sfhowes

content: Some, if not most, IMAP servers synchronize with the mail app on startup, no matter the settings in TB. That can be avoided if you launch TB in Offline mode (Settings/General/Network & Disk Space).

content:
Hola, Para diagnosticar problemas en Thunderbird, prueba la siguiente solución:

  • Reinicia Thunderbird con los complementos desactivados (Thunderbird en Modo Seguro). En el menú de Ayuda, haz clic en "Reiniciar con los complementos desactivados...". Si Thunderbird funciona bien, hay algún complemento o tema que interfiere en el funcionamiento normal de Thunderbird. Tendrás que volver a activar todos los complementos hasta que localices dónde está el problema.

Saludos
creator: pcp04

content:
default is normally just a relic. But if that is where you found your data, I'm glad you found it.

default-release is the profile which normally will be the default. Is OK to delete it if there is no useful data there. But you should be delete it using Thunderbird, not in your OS file manager. But ...

You haven't explicitly stated which profile is marked default. You cite pointing to C:\Users\carst\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\voq14rh7.default\Mail\Local Folders\Inbox.sbd. Does that mean you changed the properties of of Inbox to point to that location? Or, did you change your default profile from default-release to default?

content: You need to designate an email account as the default account. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡ > Account Settings Select the account to be the default one in the left pane. Select 'Set as Default' from the 'Account Action' drop-down menu at the bottom.

Wow where to start. My first though is the router is not even having mail ports open. Web browser traffic uses different ports to email and some products assume you do everything in your web browser.

content:
There are two possibilities I see.

1. You have not closed the welcome to Thunderbird please give at the door tab that new installs invariably have. This is just a matter of closing the tab.

2. You are seeing the standard welcome page that includes support links and donation requests in the reading pane (the part of the window that displayed the body of emails). Clicking on an email in the list will replace that with the content of the selected email.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
nikkay said
Hello Matt, It is configured as POP.

I thought it might be. I am guessing you have an antivirus program scanning mail as it is downloaded as well? Disable the email scanner and see if the issue suddenly fixes itself. That is the most likely.

Next is actual file scanning. Antivirus programs are in the habit of scanning the file system when files are opened. Unfortunately Thunderbird does not hang around waiting for hem to finish. If the file is not available it gets by without it. The result for POP mail accounts that leave mail on the server is that at times the updated status of what has been downloaded is not saved in the popstate.dat file in the accounts folder in Thunderbird's profile. The result is, the old information is what is available when the next fetch occurs. Hence duplicate emails because the downloads are not logged. This time you need to exclude the Thunderbird profile folder from on access scanning in the antivirus program.

Let me know how it goes.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Hello Matt, It is configured as POP.
creator: nikkay

content:
You will need to post the error message verbatim as the actual message is important to determine context.

Some ISPs simply block port 25 as none of their domestic customers are permitted to use a self hosted mailserver so port 25 is not a requirement and it certainly cuts down on the spam and malware making use of infected PC's to transmit mail on port 25. Blocking port 25 for domestic customers also forces commercial customers to pay for the business product to host their own mail servers.

So is the mail server you are attempting to connect to provided by your ISP and they tell you to connect on port 25? If not who is the ISP?

What is the source of the message? I just edited an SMTP entry in my version of Thundbird 115 to use port 25. It was happy to do so. No message no mess no fuss. The vague error you mention sounds like a server refusing to connect on port 25. Or perhaps some sort of third party software blocking outgoing connections on port 25 (something third party antivirus product do frequently)
creator: MattAuSupport
